items.title: usability enhancement: fail with a polite message when invoking in `src`

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

items.body:
Sometimes, due to rapid-fire directory navigation and having many unrelated items bouncing around in one's head, it's possible to invoke `colcon build` in the `src` directory of a workspace, rather than in the "root" workspace directory. This will create a new set of `build` and `install` directories as subdirectories of `src` but otherwise "seems to work" at least sometimes. This can lead to great confusion when other terminals have sourced the "original" `install` directory.

I can't quite think of a case where it's useful to run `colcon build` in a directory named `src`. I suggest that `colcon` exits with a kind and polite message like "Because I love you, I won't do what you just asked me to do. Please go up a directory and try again. Have a nice day."

I'm happy to create this PR, but wanted to ask first before proceeding.

items.title: Retest only test that fail and not entire package
items.body:
Correct me if I'm mistaken, but it seems that ~~`colcon test --retest-until-fail N`~~ `colcon test --retest-until-pass` will rerun all tests for a failing package, as opposed to only the specific tests in the package that failed. Could this be changed so the results from a previous job be used as a block list to scope which specific tests need to be repeated, not merely the package. This could help speed up CI pipelines with flaky tests.

@SteveMacenski, could you link to a previous job that exhibits the behavior you described to me offline.

items.title: Warn when building outside of workspace root

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

items.body:
I'm relatively new to ROS and I sometime find myself accidentally running `colcon build` in the wrong folder, i.e. not in the worspace root folder. This leads to `build`, `log`, and `install` folders in the wrong locations.   

I have two ideas on how this could be resolved: 

1. Warn and abort the build
2. Notify, but automatically build in the root folder

Either feature would also require some kind of `force` flag.
What do you think of this?

items.title: Seemingly infinite loop when building custom ROS2 message with long, incorrect parameter name
items.body:
Environment:
ROS2 Foxy
Following Tutorial: https://index.ros.org/doc/ros2/Tutorials/Custom-ROS2-Interfaces/#create-custom-definitions

I was following the above tutorial to create a custom message. When defining the message (specifically [here](https://index.ros.org/doc/ros2/Tutorials/Custom-ROS2-Interfaces/#msg-definition)) i changed `int64 num` into `string txt_msg_autoflow_added_to_current_ventilation_mode' `.

There are two notable differences in this change. One, the length of the variable is increased. Second, there is an illegal character `'`. When building this package, `colcon` seems to be stuck in an infinite loop.

```
# Aborting after about 9 minutes 
Starting >>> tutorial_interfaces
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                         
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                 
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
[Processing: tutorial_interfaces]                                   
Aborted  <<< tutorial_interfaces [9min 25s]     
```
If the name is shortened, such as `mode'`, i get the correct error flag:
```
 NameError: '_mode'' is an invalid field name.  It should have the pattern
  '^[a-z]([a-z0-9_]?[a-z0-9]+)*$'

```

so it seems the length of the parameter name has to do if an infinite loop occurs or not.

items.title: Vanilla CMake packages - correct CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH in dependencies
items.body:
I am trying to use colcon with vanilla CMake (without cmake-ament and ROS).

In a minimal example I have two packages, where package B contains an executable "app" which depends on "lib_a" from package A:

ws
|-package_a
|--include/lib_a.h
|--src/lib_a.cc
|--CMakeLists.txt
|--colcon.pkg
|
|-package_b
|--src/app.cc    (uses lib_a)
|--CMakeLists.txt    (with FindPackage(LibA REQUIRED))
|--colcon.pkg    (with "build-dependencies": ["package_a"])

CMakeLists.txt from "package_a" exports and installs a target "pkg_a::lib_a" in share/cmake/LibAConfig.cmake and installs the include folder and the lib.

When I build and install "package_a" manually with CMake in the first step and in a second step build "package_b" manually with CMake passing CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH to LibAConfig.cmake from step 1 everything works like expected.

I tried to build both packages automatically with colcon but failed.

The dependency graph (colcon graph) looks correct, but apparently when colcon calls CMake to configure and build package_b, it doesn't pass the CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH pointing to install/package_a/share/cmake. 

The install folder after calling colcon build looks like this:

ws
|-install
|--package_a
|---include
|----lib_a.h
|---lib
|----liblib_a.a
|---share
|----package_a
|-----hock
|------...
|-----package.bash
|-----...
|----cmake
|-----LibAConfig.cmake
|----colcon-core
|------packages
|-------package_a
|--local_setup.bash
|--....

From the documentation it is not clear how I can tell colcon to add the correct paths to the CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH from its dependencies.
Does colcon crawl the folders for "*Config.cmake" on itself files or do I have to give them explicitly somewhere?

items.title: colcon-coveragepy-result package to collect coverage.py results
items.body:
I wrote a colcon extension that collects coverage.py results: https://github.com/christophebedard/colcon-coveragepy-result

* combines `.coverage` files for each package (`ros.ament_cmake` packages might have multiple files)
* optionally prints a report for each package
* combines all `.coverage` files into one
* optionally prints a global report
* generates a global HTML report

It's basically colcon-lcov-result but for Python/coverage.py.

As per the contribution recommendations, I'd like to offer to move the repo to the colcon org.

Also, feel free to take a look at the code and review/propose changes/improvements.

items.title: colcon-ed package as replacement for rosed
items.body:
A follow up on https://github.com/ros2/ros2cli/issues/483

I have written a simple package for `colcon-ed` [here](https://github.com/Briancbn/colcon-ed).

The usage is the same as rosed with 
```
colcon edit <package_name> <filename>
```
It has the following features
- [x] Autocomplete packages (using `package_discover`)
- [x] Autocomplete files (I didn't use the extension point for this because I don't have access to already parsed arg in the extension point)
- [x] Ignore hidden folders and files, I also added in *.pyc
- [x] Use `vim` by default if `$EDITOR` environment variable is not set or set to empty, otherwise run `$EDITOR <file_path>` is if is set.
- [x] Choose which file to edit when there are multiple files under the same name within a package.

Features not supported yet
- [ ] Windows support (I don't have a Windows machine to test on)

Please let me know if colcon is interested to have this as a repository or if there are any more features needed. Since I am new here, I don't know what is needed, I have the static analysis and CI setup as the other packages here.

items.title: Command line words beginning with hyphen treated as package names, not unrecognized arguments
items.body:
Package names after `--packages-select` with leading hyphens are treated as package names, and colcon logs a warning (which may be missed among the heavy tool output). I expect such arguments to be treated as unparsed arguments and for colcon to exit with an error.

usage: colcon [-h] [--log-base LOG_BASE] [--log-level LOG_LEVEL] {build,extension-points,extensions,graph,info,list,metadata,mixin,test,test-result,version-check} ...
colcon: error: unrecognized arguments: --camke-clean-cache


$ colcon build --packages-select rcl --camke-clean-cache  
[0.745s] WARNING:colcon.colcon_core.package_selection:ignoring unknown package '--camke-clean-cache' in --packages-select

items.title: Colcon test terminates when ctrl-c is sent to a (child) subprocess on Windows
items.body:
I am currently writing E2E tests for rosbag2 using pytest. I am able to run the E2E tests successfully without the parent process dying using pytest independently. 

The test involves spawning a subprocess with `process_handle = subprocess.Popen()`and terminating it with `process_handle.send_signal(signal.CTRL_C_EVENT)`.

When the process terminates, it kills `colcon test` with an output of `Aborted`. Is there a mechanism to handle signals with colcon test? I have tried various combinations of spawning the subprocess with `Popen()` to avoid this.

* `shell=True`
* `creationflags`:
  * `CREATE_NEW_CONSOLE`
  * `CREATE_NEW_PROCESS_GROUP`
  * `DETACHED_PROCESS`

as well as creating signal handlers and wrapping things in `try`/`except` blocks.

items.title: Doesn't support CATKIN install variables
Symlink install option in Python packages overwrites data files in source directory
items.body:
We are building a Python - ROS2 package with colcon and noticed that whenever we use the --symlink-install option "some" of the data files in the source directory of our package get overwritten and become symlinks pointing to themselves, effectively breaking the source package.

We noticed this behavior with the [following package](https://github.com/osrf/traffic_editor/) (master branch), steps to reproduce:

- Create a colcon workspace, clone the package into src directory
- Source ROS2 eloquent
- Run colcon build --symlink-install

Command output:

```Starting >>> building_map_msgs
Starting >>> traffic_editor
[Processing: building_map_msgs, traffic_editor]                                                               
Finished <<< building_map_msgs [31.7s]                                                                         
Starting >>> building_map_tools
Finished <<< traffic_editor [32.0s]                                                                 
--- stderr: building_map_tools                    
error: can't copy 'building_map_generators/textures/blue_linoleum.png': doesn't exist or not a regular file
---
Failed   <<< building_map_tools	[ Exited with code 1 ]
                                 
Summary: 2 packages finished [32.9s]
  1 package failed: building_map_tools
  1 package had stderr output: building_map_tools
```
Now when checking the source directory:
```
cd src/traffic_editor
git status
```
This is the output
```
On branch master
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/master'.

Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)

	typechange: building_map_tools/building_map_generators/textures/blue_linoleum.png
	typechange: building_map_tools/building_map_generators/textures/blue_linoleum_high_contrast.png
	typechange: building_map_tools/building_map_generators/textures/wall.png

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
```
The data files became symlinks pointing to themselves.

I tried to have a look at the code that is doing the linking and copying [here](https://github.com/colcon/colcon-core/blob/master/colcon_core/task/python/build.py#L221) but when I added a few debug print statements I noticed that the files in the build space exist even before that part of the code runs, so got a bit lost.

Something interesting I found is that if the data files are in the same folder as the setup.py the wrong behavior does not occur and everything works fine!
```
cd src/traffic_editor/building_map_tools
cp building_map_generators/textures/* .
vim setup.py # Edit the data files path to point to package root directory
```

If you have any suggestion on what might be wrong I can have a look as well.

Cheers
/Luca

items.title: Confusing interaction between --base-paths and --paths
items.body:
When searching for one package by path using `colcon info --paths /path/to/package`, colcon performed recursive package discovery. This seems to be because I set my `base-paths` in the defaults yaml file. Passing `--base-path "."` makes colcon only discover the package as specified.

defaults.yaml:
```
...
info:
  base-paths: [src]
```

`colcon list --paths-only`

> /opt/ros/master/src/ApexAI/performance_test/performance_test
> /opt/ros/master/src/ament/ament_cmake/ament_cmake
> ...

`colcon list --paths-only --paths src/ros2/rmw/rmw`

> /opt/ros/master/src/ApexAI/performance_test/performance_test
> /opt/ros/master/src/ament/ament_cmake/ament_cmake
> ...

` colcon list --paths-only --paths src/ros2/rmw/rmw --base-paths .`
> /opt/ros/master
> /opt/ros/master/src/ros2/rmw/rmw
(even though I have a top-level CMakeLists.txt in the current directory, this is unexpected)

`colcon list --paths-only --paths src/ros2/rmw/rmw --base-paths ""`
`colcon list --paths-only --paths src/ros2/rmw/rmw --base-paths ''`
`colcon list --paths-only --paths src/ros2/rmw/rmw --base-paths`
> /opt/ros/master/src/ros2/rmw/rmw

This is the expected result.

It seems that passing `--paths` on the command line should cause colcon to not recurse through base-paths in the yaml file. Better yet, have no special handling here and set the default '--paths' value to `"**"`

items.title: Colcon does not log where it's expected to
items.body:
Colcon logging options don't work as documented. It seems, contrary to the documentation, that:

1. `$COLCON_HOME ` is ignored for determining the logging location. Relative paths are always resolved relative to cwd. (in particular `COLCON_LOG_PATH is documented as defaulting to `$COLCON_HOME/log`, which is not the case)
2. `COLCON_LOG_PATH` handles `/dev/null` as documented, whereas `--log-base` crashes. This crash does not appear to produce log files anywhere.
3. Contrary to expectation, `COLCON_LOG_PATH` takes priority over the `--log-base` argument

```
$ colcon --help
...
optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --log-base LOG_BASE   The base path for all log directories (default: log,
                        to disable: /dev/null)
  --log-level LOG_LEVEL
                        Set log level for the console output, either by
                        numeric or string value (default: warn)
...
Environment variables:
...
  COLCON_HOME           Set the configuration directory (default: ~/.colcon)
  COLCON_LOG_LEVEL      Set the log level (debug|10, info|20, warn|30,
                        error|40, critical|50, or any other positive numeric
                        value)
  COLCON_LOG_PATH       Set the log directory (default: $COLCON_HOME/log, to
                        disable: /dev/null)
```

test setup:
```
$ function logtest {
rm -rf /tmp/ws/ /tmp/colcon/ ~/.colcon/log
mkdir -p /tmp/ws/ /tmp/colcon/ ~/.colcon
cd /tmp/ws
eval ${1}
find ~/.colcon /tmp/colcon /tmp/ws -name log
}
```
test results (same in both zsh and bash):
```

$ logtest "COLCON_HOME=/tmp/colcon colcon list"

$ logtest "COLCON_HOME=/tmp/colcon COLCON_LOG_PATH=log colcon list"
/tmp/ws/log

$ logtest "COLCON_LOG_PATH=/dev/null colcon list"
$ logtest "colcon --log-base /dev/null list"

items.title: Colcon shell.get_environment_variables does not correctly handle some Windows environment variables
items.body:
When colcon_core.shell.get_environment_variables() is decoding the environment variable string, it makes invalid assumptions about the format of a valid environment variable key. Specifically, it uses the regular expression: '^[a-zA-Z0-9_%]+$' (around line 328). This does not correctly handle the environment variable strings `PROGRAMFILES(X86)` (cmd) or `ProgramFiles(x86)` (PowerShell). Instead, this environment variable and its key are appented to the previous environment variable, pontetially invalidating that variable.

This can result in a polluted environment causing downstream issues. See https://github.com/colcon/colcon-cmake/issues/54

The expected behaviour is that `PROGRAMFILES(X86)` is stored as its own key/value pair in the resulting environment dictionary and other valid variables are not polluted.

One potential fix is to use a different regular expression for Windows, allowing '(' and ')' characters.

items.title: Misleadingly named check_call function
items.body:
Discovered when doing #235.

colcon_core.task contains its own [`check_call` function](https://github.com/colcon/colcon-core/blob/bb615dffe8282e5b7364534d90d8e48b06c9b6ea/colcon_core/task/__init__.py#L121) that does not actually check the result and raise an error. This is confusingly similar to the built in [`subprocess.check_call` function](https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html?highlight=check_call#subprocess.check_call) function that does.

Perhaps when addressing this, we should take the opportunity to use asyncio subprocess functions [asycio.create_subprocess_exec/asyncio.create_subprocess_shell](https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-subprocess.html#subprocesses).

items.title: Colcon builds each python package thrice
items.body:
When you colcon-build a Python Package without `--symlink-install`, it build the package three times.

**First build:**
The `egg_info`, `build` commands build the package in `.egg-info` distribution format. This build is never used.
https://github.com/colcon/colcon-core/blob/af5b8862136ed18fef529745613e16998c3af888/colcon_core/task/python/build.py#L113-L115

**Second build:**
The `install` command without `--skip-build` causes, *another* build. This is an `.egg-info` distribution instead of an `.egg` format because of the flag `--single-version-externally-managed`
https://github.com/colcon/colcon-core/blob/af5b8862136ed18fef529745613e16998c3af888/colcon_core/task/python/build.py#L116-L119

**Third build:**
The `bdist_egg` builds the package in `.egg` distribution format. Aside from being redundant (the egg created with `bdist_egg` is never actually installed), this will cause a crash on packages that prefer `distutils.core.setup` instead of `setuptools.setup`. I don't know if this is a supported use case but these *are* compliant python packages.
https://github.com/colcon/colcon-core/blob/af5b8862136ed18fef529745613e16998c3af888/colcon_core/task/python/build.py#L123-L124

It would be best to build the package exactly once.

items.title: Question | Could mixin/extensions be used for supporting incremental build and test?
items.body:
Say a user has built a workspace and subsequently runs colcon test. The user then modifies a number of files in the workspace and again invokes `colcon build` and then `colcon test`. Ideally, one could expect packages that are were modified, as well packages above those modified, to be rebuilt. Then for testing, only those packages rebuilt, would be retested. Thus the caching of build and test would be maximized, yet still encompassing all changes to the workspace since the previous build and test.

Would this be achievable using mixins and extensions? Or would core changes be required?

I'm thinking an extension could retain a digest-manifest for all files in the workspace, so it could be fully aware of file level changes. Those file changes could then be associated to package names that then could be passed to colcon build and test arg, e.g.

```
colcon build --mixin incremental
->> expands to ->>
colcon build --packages-above <modified_packages> \
    --packages-select-build-failed
```

```
colcon test --mixin incremental
->> expands to ->>
colcon test --packages-above <rebuilt_packages> \
    --packages-select-test-failures
```

BTW, are the sets of packages captured by each arg `OR`'d or `AND`'d together?
And would something like `incremental clean` vs `incremental dirty` be helpful for specifying whether effected packages should be cleaned or not prior to build or test? Related: https://github.com/colcon/colcon-core/issues/37

items.title: Colcon logging incurs significant overhead on Windows
items.body:
Hi,

I've noted that colcon incurs significant overheads when logging on Windows. This is on top of it being significantly slower on Windows vs Linux.

Attached is a helloworld colcon project which deliberately generates log spam during CMake configuration. The `README.md` file contains instructions on how to run colcon to show differences between default logging, console only logging and no logging as well as the performance summary, duplicated in the table below.

OS        | File logging  | Console logging | No logging
--------- | ------------- | --------------- | --------------
Windows   | 35.2s         | 12.8s           | 12.2s
Linux     | 0.55s         | 0.44s           | 0.46s

And yes, Linux is generally nearly two orders of magnitude faster.

[slowcolcon.zip](https://github.com/colcon/colcon-core/files/3523303/slowcolcon.zip)

  set(CMAKE_C_FLAGS "${CMAKE_C_FLAGS} -Wall -Wextra -Werror")
  set(OS_LIBS pthread pcap)
elseif(${CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME} MATCHES "rt-kernel")
  set(OS "rtk")
  message("ARCH is ${ARCH}")
  message("BSP is ${BSP}")
  include_directories(oshw/${OS}/${ARCH})
  file(GLOB OSHW_EXTRA_SOURCES oshw/${OS}/${ARCH}/*.c)
  set(OSHW_SOURCES "${OS_HW_SOURCES} ${OSHW_ARCHSOURCES}")
  set(CMAKE_C_FLAGS "${CMAKE_C_FLAGS} -Wall -Wextra -Werror")
  set(CMAKE_C_FLAGS "${CMAKE_C_FLAGS} -Wno-unused-but-set-variable")
  set(CMAKE_C_FLAGS "${CMAKE_C_FLAGS} -Wno-unused-function")
  set(CMAKE_C_FLAGS "${CMAKE_C_FLAGS} -Wno-format")
  set(OS_LIBS "-Wl,--start-group -l${BSP} -l${ARCH} -lkern -ldev -lsio -lblock -lfs -lusb -llwip -leth -li2c -lrtc -lcan -lnand -lspi -lnor -lpwm -ladc -ltrace -lc -lm -Wl,--end-group")
elseif(${CMAKE_SYSTEM_NAME} MATCHES "rtems")
  message("Building for RTEMS")
  set(OS "rtems")
  set(SOEM_LIB_INSTALL_DIR ${LIB_DIR})
  set(BUILD_TESTS FALSE)
endif()

message("OS is ${OS}")

file(GLOB SOEM_SOURCES soem/*.c)
file(GLOB OSAL_SOURCES osal/${OS}/*.c)
file(GLOB OSHW_SOURCES oshw/${OS}/*.c)

file(GLOB SOEM_HEADERS soem/*.h)
file(GLOB OSAL_HEADERS osal/osal.h osal/${OS}/*.h)
file(GLOB OSHW_HEADERS oshw/${OS}/*.h)

include_directories(soem)
include_directories(osal)
include_directories(osal/${OS})
include_directories(oshw/${OS})

add_library(soem STATIC
  ${SOEM_SOURCES}
  ${OSAL_SOURCES}
  ${OSHW_SOURCES}
  ${OSHW_EXTRA_SOURCES})
target_link_libraries(soem ${OS_LIBS})

message("LIB_DIR: ${SOEM_LIB_INSTALL_DIR}")

install(TARGETS soem DESTINATION ${SOEM_LIB_INSTALL_DIR})
install(FILES
  ${SOEM_HEADERS}
  ${OSAL_HEADERS}
  ${OSHW_HEADERS}
  DESTINATION ${SOEM_INCLUDE_INSTALL_DIR})
``` 
I tested with different messages and showed same stderr output.
If the messages are commeted out, colcon showed success with no error.

Thank you in advance.

items.title: Colcon missing an install verb
items.body:
Catkin used to distinguish between `catkin_make` and `catkin_make install DESTDIR=...`, whereas Colcon has only `colcon build` with or without symlinks.

Looking beyond the Debian ecosystem, the RPM packaging format strictly separates `%build` and `%install` phases, of which only `%install` shall access the destination directory.

So it would seem we need something like `colcon build --no-install` and `colcon install` to be able to use it for other distros, such as openSUSE.

Or is Colcon only intended for local user builds? Should we rather be using CMake directly somehow? Catkin used to generate a `CMakeLists.txt` file in the base directory that we'd be missing out on then.

items.title: `colcon build` on OSX is orders of magnitude slower than direct `make`
items.body:
I have a workspace set up on Mac with source checked out from https://github.com/ros2/ros2/blob/master/ros2.repos

On: Macbook Pro 15 inch 2017, 2.9 GHz Intel Core i7, 16 GB 2133 MHz LPDDR3
Running High Sierra 10.13.6

Using https://github.com/ros2/rcl/blob/master/rcl/test/rcl/test_events.cpp as example file, arbitrarily chosen - triggers minimal rebuild because it is a leaf executable.

* Build once from nothing `colcon build --packages-up-to rcl`
* Change one line in example file, then `colcon build --packages-select rcl`
    * Takes ~5 minutes to complete
* Change one line then `cd build/rcl; make install`  note that this is single threaded
    * ~15 seconds
* Change one line then `cd build/rcl; make -j$(sysctl -n hw.logicalcpu) install`
    * ~7 seconds

There is of course some overhead to be expected from the tool, but this seems clearly outside the expectation. Probably something weird is going on that makes everything go really slow.

items.title: don't create build/install/log folder if no packages were found
items.body:
It happened a couple of times now that I invoke `colcon build --packages-select <package_name>` in the wrong directory. Obviously, the package in question is not being found and thus no compilation is triggered. However, what's a bit annoying is that the `build`, `install` and `log` folders are created which I then have to remove manually.

I know this is wrong user behavior, but I believe it makes sense to check whether at least one package can be compiled before creating these folders.

items.title: Colcon runs in global interpreter
items.body:
The colcon executable installed through apt has a shebang of `#!/usr/bin/python3`.
This prevents use in different virtual environments, especially since this shebang then puts the global python shebang into scripts built with colcon.

One (or more) of the following would make this easier:
- Recommended to install colcon-core locally (instead of globally with apt as per https://colcon.readthedocs.io/en/released/user/installation.html).
- Change the shebang on colcon to `/usr/bin/env python3`.
- Colcon should respect the Python interpreter specified with `$COLCON_PYTHON_EXECUTABLE` when building other python projects.

```
➜  ros2_ws git:(master) ✗ cat `which colcon`
#!/usr/bin/python3
# EASY-INSTALL-ENTRY-SCRIPT: 'colcon-core==0.3.20','console_scripts','colcon'
__requires__ = 'colcon-core==0.3.20'
import re
...
```

items.title: Remove explicit quoting of --*cmake-args arguments
items.body:
As stated in #18, colcon requires arguments passed to `--*cmake-args` to be quoted.
This is rather unnatural. I suggest to follow the standard, also used in catkin_tools any many other cmdline tools, and consume all arguments after `--*cmake-args` for this list. A final `--` indicates the end of the list.

items.title: --event-handlers args: inconsistency between code and doc
items.body:
While `colcon build --help suggest`, that `--event-handlers` accepts both `+` and `-` versions of all names:
```
Event handler arguments:
  --event-handlers [name1+ [name2- ...]]
                        Enable (+) or disable (-) event handlers
```

colcon actually complains when passing `console_stderr+`:
`colcon build: error: argument --event-handlers: invalid choice: 'console_stderr+' (choose from 'console_cohesion+', 'console_direct+', 'console_package_list+', 'console_start_end-', 'console_stderr-', 'desktop_notification-', 'event_log-', 'log-', 'log_command-', 'status-', 'store_result-', 'summary-', 'terminal_title-')`

I suggest to indeed accept both +/- versions to allow for explicit statement of desired output mode.

items.title: Symlink install of data_files for python setuptools packages
items.body:
This is especially useful for, e.g. ros2 launch files that need to reside in `share/<package_name>`. Currently, if you have

```
    ....
    data_files=[
        ('share/' + package_name, ['package.xml', 'my.launch.py']),
    ],
    ....
```
Then `package.xml` gets symlinked but the launch files do not:

```
package.bash
package.ps1
package.sh
my.launch.py
package.xml -> /my_workspace/src/my_package/package.xml
package.zsh
```
Symlink install handling is in `colcon_core/task/python/__init__.py`. @dirk-thomas mentioned that pulling the information from `setup.py` to unwind the install and replace with symlinks is difficult and potentially unreliable (depending on whatever other programmatic mischief is going on in `setup.py`) and a better place to define the information is in `setup.cfg`.

`options.data_files` is not supported in setuptools on bionic though (`v39.0.1`). Seems the version necessary may be `v40.5.0` (setuptools issue 1522) and may have issues with [dashes](https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/pull/1520#issuecomment-451517088).

items.title: Documentation unclear on how to build with no more than one thread/job
items.body: The documentation on https://colcon.readthedocs.io/en/released/migration/ament_tools.html is unclear on how to specify the number of build jobs, which has been possible with ament. Using four or more build jobs prevents building large codebases like ROS 2 on low-memory hardware with colcon. Though there is a sequential option, the package processed is still built with multiple jobs when invoking `colcon build --executor sequential`. It would be most helpful, if the linked documentation page would comment on the availability of specifying the number of build jobs, and if available, how to.

items.title: Errors sourcing local_setup.sh from zsh
items.body:
When building colcon in a bootstrap source workspace, sourcing the `local_setup.sh` generated is unsuccessful in ZSH.

When sourcing, the script doesn't correctly split the list of packages based on newlines as expected.

```
(colcon-venv) ➜  colcon-from-source $ . install/local_setup.sh 
not found: "/home/michael/colcon-venv/colcon-from-source/install/colcon-core
<SNIPPED FOR LENGTH>
colcon-test-result/package.sh"
```

This is caused by `zsh`'s handling of `IFS` and has been previously handled in other shell scripts via the `colcon_zsh_convert_array` function (eg https://github.com/colcon/colcon-core/blob/master/colcon_core/shell/template/package.sh.em#L23)

The expected behavior is that the shell script successfully executes under a `zsh` shell.

items.title: Cannot find requisite cpp files for setuptools
items.body:
In `src/xlib/`, I have a setup.py which is build a Python C++ extension using setuptools. When `python3 setup.py build_ext` is run within that directory, the build completes successfully. However, when running `colcon build --symlink-install` from the workspace root, I get the following errors:
```
x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc: error: PythonBindings.cpp: No such file or directory
x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc: fatal error: no input files
compilation terminated.
error: command 'x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc' failed with exit status 1
---
```
It seems that colcon is not copying over the source files to the build folder at `build/xlib`, and thus the setup.py is unable to build the extension. I am unable to find documentation or sources to help me do this.

`colcon build` completes successfully, but obviously leaves the built `xlib.cpython-*-.so` in the `src/xlib` folder.

```python
sources=[
        'PythonBindings.cpp',
        'Other.cpp',
        'Example.cpp'
]
lib_module = Extension(
    'xlib',
    sources=sources,
    language='C++',
    extra_compile_args=['-std=c++14'],
    libraries=['stdc++'],
    include_dirs=[numpy.get_include(), get_python_inc()]
)

setup(
    name='lib_bindings',
    version='1.0.0',
    packages=[],
    author='Ritwik Gupta',
    author_email='x@x.cmu.edu',
    maintainer='Ritwik Gupta',
    maintainer_email='x@x.cmu.edu',
    keywords=['x'],
    classifiers=[],
    description='x',
    ext_modules=[lib_module],
    package_data={
        '': ['PythonBindings.cpp', '*.h', '*.c']
    },
    include_package_data=True
)
```

items.title: Colcon dry run
items.body:
We're using bazel as our build system, which to build ROS calls into colcon. Unfortunately, bazel likes to know a complete list of files that will be generated ahead-of-time. Right now, my workaround is to build once, inspect the files created, then give that list to bazel so it can manage builds from now on.

I'd love to streamline this process. In particular, it would be ideal if there was a way to get colcon to do a "dry run", and report what files it _would_ create, without actually doing the builds. Is this currently possible? Or a possible feature? I'm happy to help with implementation if it's not a huge amount of work.

items.title: colcon.pkg is read but not used
Colcon extension for coverage results
items.body:
## Description 
- As a follow up for #94, I want to work on a `colcon` extension to parse gcov/lcov coverage result files. I'm thinking of naming it `colcon-lcov-result`. Below is my proposal and I'm looking for some feedback before I dive in. Thanks!

## Motivation
To be able to visualize coverage results in C/C++ code using the [lcov tool](http://ltp.sourceforge.net/coverage/lcov.php)

## Proposed workflow
```
colcon build --mixin coverage-gcc
colcon test
colcon lcov-result
chromium-browser lcov/index.html
```

For a single package:
```
colcon lcov-result  --zero-counters
colcon test --packages-select my_pkg
colcon lcov-result --packages-select my_pkg
chromium-browser lcov/index.html
```

To find packages with no coverage:
```
colcon build --mixin coverage-gcc
colcon lcov-result --baseline
colcon test
colcon lcov-result
chromium-browser lcov/index.html
```

### Command and options
- `colcon lcov-result`: 
   1. Calls `lcov --capture ...` for each package
   2. If a baseline is available, it combines the results of each package with its baseline (see below for more details)
   3. Combines the results of all selected packages into one coverage result such that it can generate a static html site (in `ros2_ws/lcov/`) (`lcov --add-tracefile` + `genhtml`)

- `colcon lcov-result --baseline`:
  - Calls `lcov --initial --capture...` to generate a zero-coverage baseline for each package
      - If a file has zero tests, `lcov` will ignore it. This baseline combined with the actual coverage will reveal these files (see ii. above)

- `colcon lcov-result --zero-counters`:
   - Calls `lcov --zerocounters ...` on each package
   - This would allow you to clear the results and re-run tests 
       - For example, if you initially ran two tests and subsequently want to run them individually.

items.title: Package configuration syntax is inconsistent
items.body:
Hi,

I've been playing around with package configuration - specifically setting CMake options - and I've identified the three different configuration files using two different configuration syntaxes:

1. Global configuration using `COLCON_DEFAULTS_FILE` environment variable and/or `defaults.yaml` (YAML) file
2. Package specific configuration using `colcon.meta` (YAML) file in the project root
3. Package specific configuration using `colcon.pkg` (JSON) file in the package root

Two of these are YAML based, and one is JSON, while the available keywords are consistent between them. For example, I can specify `cmake-args` in any of the three files.

Is there a good reason for having the `colcon.pkg` file use JSON and not YAML?

items.title: [colcon-parallel-executor] Unable to stop `test` with Ctrl+C when testing in parallel
items.body:
If I run `colcon test` on a workspace and try to interrupt it, it aborts the current tasks but trigger the following packages anyway.

If I use `--executor sequential` it works fine (abort the current package and doesnt trigger the following ones).

items.title: Add build option for coverage
items.body:
# Description
- In order to get coverage output that can be parsed by tools like gcov, it is necessary to build with special flags:  `-fprofile-arcs` and `-ftest-coverage`
- This currently means that one must add the following arguments to `colcon build`:

    ```
    --ament-cmake-args -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS="${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS}  -fprofile-arcs -ftest-coverage " -DCMAKE_C_FLAGS="${CMAKE_C_FLAGS}  -fprofile-arcs -ftest-coverage "
    ```
- For example, see https://ci.ros2.org/view/nightly/job/nightly_linux_coverage/210/consoleFull
- While this is manageable in a CI server, it is burdensome when trying to generate coverage locally because of the length of the argument and the subtleties of escaping the arguments for CMake.

- This issue proposes adding a flag (e.g., `--with-coverage-flags`) to `colcon build` which wraps the long arguments above. 
- Naturally, for other supported compilers (clang?), the `with-coverage-flags` option could also handle the specific compile flags.

## Motivation
- Making it easier for developers to generate coverage locally

## Expected  behavior

```
colcon build --with-coverage --ament-cmake-args <other args>
````
works like
```
colcon build --ament-cmake-args -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS="${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS}  -fprofile-arcs -ftest-coverage " -DCMAKE_C_FLAGS="${CMAKE_C_FLAGS}  -fprofile-arcs -ftest-coverage " <other args>
```

- Optionally, it could be useful to also include `-DCOVERAGE_RUN=1` such that developers can adjust test behavior during coverage test runs.
    - For example, any timing-sensitive tests will tend to fail during coverage runs because of the extra CPU cycles, so the threshold for timeouts may need to be adjusted: e.g.,
```
#ifdef COVERAGE_RUN
    timeout = 20
#else
    timeout = 5
#endif
```

## Future work
- There could also be an extension to `colcon test_results` to digest coverage results: e.g.,

```
colcon build --with-coverage
colcon test
colcon test_results --output-coverage
```

items.title: python3-colcon `colcon build` reports an error on Ubuntu Xenial
items.body:
`colcon build` on an ubuntu:xenial container reports the following error:

```
ERROR:colcon.colcon_core.entry_point:Exception loading extension 'colcon_core.package_identification.python': No module named 'setuptools.config'
```

It looks like the system packaged `setuptools` doesn't include this module in xenial - this can be worked around by upgrading the system `setuptools` using `sudo python3 -m pip install setuptools -U`.

items.title: Better error msg if compile-time Python not found at sourcing time on Windows
items.body:
Since https://github.com/colcon/colcon-core/pull/70 we use Python to source packages in topological order.
If the python executable is not found it crashes with `The system cannot find the path specified.`

We should provide a better error message so that users know what fails.

One way to do it might be to check that the file exist before calling it. But it may be to expensive...

items.title: add a flag to colcon build similar to ament_tools `--build-tests`
items.body:
Currently colcon documentation says that to build tests people should:
```
ament: --build-tests
colcon: --cmake-args " -DBUILD_TESTING=1"
```
But `BUILD_TESTING` is ON by default in CTest so if users don't pass the option the tests are built anyway: https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.7/module/CTest.html

We could first change the documentaiton to reflect this.
A better (maybe further looking) alternative would be to implement an equivalent to `--build-tests` in colcon. This would allow users to pass a single flags to build the tests of their heterogeneous workspaces (in the case where multiple build systems are involved and all have a different way of specifying test building).

items.title: support installing to same prefix from different workspaces
items.body:
Currently the prefix-level scripts contain a list of packages in the workspace. The advantage of that approach is that no crawling of the file system is necessary when sourcing the script.

In order to support installing into the same prefix from multiple workspaces the list of packages needs to be collected by crawling the file system, ordering the packages topologically and sourcing each package. Parsing the package manifests will not be sufficient since some package might not have one and their dependencies were determined using external information which is not available in the install prefix anymore.

items.title: Support environment variable expansion in configuration files?
items.body:
I use environment variables in my ament aliases, for example to construct build/install destination based on the workspace I'm building and the parameters I uese to build it.

Is the recommended way to do this with colcon to create bash aliases to expand these variable and to invoke colcon or is there a plan to support such use cases in the colcon configuration system?

items.title: Ability to pass additional configuration file to colcon via commandline?
items.body:
I'd like to be able to pass global configuration files to colcon when invoking it.

Currently the only way to do it is to set the environment variable ation `COLCON_DEFAULTS_FILE` at invocation time. But this override the defaults and doesn't extend them.
Is there a way to extend the default configuration with another configuration file?

items.title: colcon executable installed for packages other than colcon-core
items.body: Follow up of colcon/colcon-notification#4. "Sometimes" packages other than `colcon-core` end up having a `bin/colcon` executable installed into their isolated install prefix.

items.title: Create repository for colcon-gradle
items.body:
I'm porting https://github.com/esteve/ament_java to colcon and given that the recommended process is to create a repo under the colcon organization to store any extenions (http://colcon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/developer/contribution.html#new-packages-extensions) I'm asking for one here, though I don't know if this is the correct repo for filing a ticket for that.

Thanks!

items.title: consider custom parsing logic to avoid leading space for nested arguments
items.body: Currently nested arguments like `--cmake-args` need to be prefixes with a space in order to not be considered by `argparse`. If that should be avoided custom argument parsing logic needs to be implemented which pre-processes the arguments to extract all following parameters up to a `--`.

items.title: consider failing or warning in case of problems in extensions
items.body: I created this "meta" issue based on the discussion today. Please suggest specific cases where the current behavior should be changed.
